title-group.article-title: The Primitive as Analyst: Postcolonial Feminism's Access to Psychoanalysis

ref.mixed-citation: Elizabeth Grosz in The Post-Colonial Critic

Spivak sug- gests that it may be necessary to specify subjectivity outside the discourses of psy- choanalysis and counter-psychoanalysis by tracking what she terms "regulative psycho-biographies" (9-10)

"Dark Continents," Doane says: Psychoanalysis can. .. be seen as a quite elaborate form of ethnogra- phy-as a writing of the white Western psyche.... What is at issue ... [is] the question of psychoanalytic knowledge and who can lay claim to its possession.... [and] who has the right to speak as a psy- choanalyst. (211-12)

Abdul JanMohamed's characterization of colonialist practices as organized by the trope of Manichean allegory. He says: This economy [of colonialist representation] ... is based on a trans- formation of racial difference into moral and even metaphysical dif- ference. ... Even the works of some of the most enlightened and crit- ical colonial writers eventually succumb to a narrative organization based on racial/metaphysical oppositions, whose motives remain mor- ally fixed ... (80)

Freud's letter to Romain Rolland in 1930: "I shall now try with your guidance to penetrate into the Indian jungle from which until now an uncertain blending of Hellenic love of proportion, Jewish sobriety, and philistine timidity have kept me away" (VFD 943)
